abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts were substantial. Given the nature of
            the project - a geothermal operation - several new lessons
            suggest the following. Major positive lessons learned from
            the project demonstrated: a) the many possibilities for
            using low temperature-based geothermal energy in Lithuania;
            b) the high potential for the development, and construction
            of geothermal energy plants in other locations in Lithuania;
            c) existing opportunities for using geothermal energy for
            other purposes, for example health care, medicine, tourism,
            relaxation etc.; d) that the cost price of heat energy
            produced in a geothermal plant is lower than traditionally
            produced heat; and, e) that heat produced in a geothermal
            plant can substitute for the use of large amounts of fossil
            fuels, and contribute to reduced greenhouse gas emissions,
            thereby having a clear and positive effect on the global
            environment. Notwithstanding, major negative lessons convey:
            1)the inadequate location of the first injection well,
            suggesting Enterprise Geotherma (EG) should have been more
            insistent during the decision making process, avoiding the
            unforeseen additional cost for a second injection well; 2)
            insufficient analysis of geothermal water: a more prudent
            analysis would have raised the gypsum problem, and included
            same in the Project design; 3) control of the water flow and
            temperature should have been done at time of drilling the
            wells, instead of at the time of equipment delivery; 4) more
            intensive supervision and technical assistance by the Danish
            consultant during Project implementation, could have reduced
            the time needed for start up, and to solve technical
            problems. Other lessons suggest over estimated demand
            forecasts for the overall heat needs of Klaipeda, following
            the conversion to a market economy, and, in the event of a
            future geothermal operation, it is highly recommended that
            the plant be part of the district heating company, in order
            to optimize benefits (environmental, economic and financial).
